description: Functions of several variables, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives and applications, double and triple integrals, conic sections, polar coordinates, vectors and analytic geometry, first and second order ordinary differential equations. Applications to physical sciences. Use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
name: CALCULUS II

values.comments:
The second in a four-part calculus sequence, Math 114 deals with functions of multiple variables, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives and their applications, double and triple integrals, and differential equations, among other topics. The textbook used is the sixth edition of Stewart’s “Calculus.” The course serves as good preparation for more advanced mathematics courses, as well as those in mathematically intensive fields such as the Natural Sciences, Economics and Engineering.

Most students claimed they did not gain much from this course and were in fact discouraged from the entire subject by it. One student said it helped his “calculation skills,” while others contended that the textbook was extremely good.

Professor Pimsner received negative reviews because he appeared to be detached from the class and teaching it as a mere formality. His lectures were unclear, boring and at times confusing which led many students to skip class and study on their own. Students also complained that he taught directly from the textbook and did not bring outside examples that would have benefited the class. The professor often failed to inspire student interest.

Students said grading on exams was unfair because 7 out of 10 questions were multiple choice with no chance at partial credit. One student commented that “If you are a major, go into 116. If not, don't take the class.”

The second in a four-part calculus sequence, Math 114 deals with functions of multiple variables, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives and their applications, double and triple integrals, and differential equations, among other topics. The textbook used is the sixth edition of Stewart’s “Calculus.” The course serves as good preparation for more advanced mathematics courses, as well as those in mathematically intensive fields such as the Natural Sciences, Economics and Engineering.

Many students praised the class saying it was useful and helped them understand the fundamentals of calculus. Others suggested that the textbook was extremely useful in helping them get a grip on the topics covered.

Many students felt Professor Pantev was an “effective and interesting” teacher, though some students took objection to the fast-paced nature of the class. In addition, students commented that lectures go deeper than needed to prepare for tests. Students said he was knowledgeable and extremely willing to help out with questions, regardless of whether they were obvious or complex.

Students said grading on exams was unfair because 7 out of 10 questions were multiple choice with no chance at partial credit. Meanwhile, students highly praised the textbook. It was a strong recommendation from many students that majors in fields other than Engineering and the Sciences do not take this course.

The second in a four-part calculus sequence, Math 114 deals with functions of multiple variables, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives and their applications, double and triple integrals, and differential equations, among other topics. The textbook used is the sixth edition of Stewart’s “Calculus.” The course serves as good preparation for more advanced mathematics courses, as well as those in mathematically intensive fields such as the Natural Sciences, Economics and Engineering.

Many students questioned the usefulness of the course and commented that the course could be extremely dry and boring. It catered well to the needs of some students as Professor Zhu largely applied mathematical concepts to fields such as engineering. One student said he felt like he knew the “material like the back of [his] hand.”

Students described Professor Zhu as a “relatively good” professor. She was open to answering questions and responsive during office hours. Some people however, had problems with her clarity and her ability to converse fluently in English. Others commended her enthusiasm and depth of resources.

Students said the course required a lot of work and exams were usually out of the ordinary and required a deeper than superficial understanding of the concepts covered in lectures. Students recommended the class for engineering, math and chemistry majors, and strongly discouraged others from pursuing the course.
